Nah, Tolstoy was dead wrong. I can't even imagine the research he did to arrive at such a silly conclusion. I have a happy family and it bears little resemblance to most other families I've encountered. Maybe Leo was afflicted with the religious fallacy that good=boring, harps, clouds and the like. I know Tolstoy was a literary genius, but this oft quoted line is really just plain stupid.

Tolstoy was not much of a role model when it came to his own family. Neither was Ghandi.  He slept with virgins to prove his own purity.  How sick was that?  What did he do when he messed up? Ooops? I was so disappointed when I found that out.  Just because a man is a brilliant author or a leader of people, idealists, etc, when it comes down to himself, it is all about himself.  Ditto with everyone of these jokers running for office. I have hope in President Obama.  If Michelle can put up with him, he is all right with me. It seems to me, she suffers no fools.  Tolstoy's wife was hopelessly in love, but he became nuts, eaten up with his own importance.  I don't think the three females would allow that in President Obama's family. In that way, President Obama is blessed and is a better leader because of it.

Miller's plays sometimes had dual political and psychological overtones like Death of a Salesman and All My Sons. I think the cultural ramifications are more significant.

Tolstoy said that all happy families were the same, while all unhappy ones are unique to themselves. The same can be said of neurotic people.
All relatively healthy are similar, but deeply disturbed, tragic people, like Willy Loman and his son are unique unto themselves.

Sophocles's original Oedipus Rex is more believable than Freud's theory. Freud thinks the son wants to posses the mother, even sexually. His wishes to kill his father. He thinks his father will punish him for these thoughts by cutting off his penis.(castration). He resolves this by repressing the entire thing, identifying with his father and getting his own gal. This is as plausible a theory as trickle down economics. Freud had valuable insights, but the centrality of the Oedipal conflict has been largely discredited, especially as a universal theory of personality.

Actually originally Freud's patients overwhelmingly told stories of parental sexual abuse. He called this the Seduction Theory of Neurosis. Colleagues told him that this was too controversial and radical for Victorian culture so he "revised" his thinking by stating that children had the wish for and fantasized about sexual contact with parents, and it was this wish, and not the actual memory that was repressed

"The essence of the Wanniski argument was that each political party needed to be a different sort of Santa Claus. The Democrats were the spending Santa Claus, promising more government benefits. The Republicans should be the tax-cut Santa Claus, he said. Many of the nation’s problems in 1976 stemmed from the unwillingness of Republicans to play that proper role. Instead of being the tax-cut Santa, they had become the party of fiscal austerity. The balanced budget was the sine qua non of Republican economic policy. This was both bad economics and bad politics, Mr. Wanniski said. Instead of worrying about the deficit, he said, Republicans should just cut taxes and push for faster growth, which would make the debt more bearable."

And this is where Mr. Wanninski took the Republican party off course. Instead of modeling tax policy after the failed Democratic spending policies of the 1970's they should have modeled it after the successful policies of Paul Volcker's fed.

Paul Volcker understood a hell of lot more about economics than most of the politicians out there. Conservative economics rests on three principles:

1. The federal government is not a charity - don't give things away
2. The federal government is not your best buddy - don't play favorites
3. The federal government is not a global police force - fighting is always the last option

My pediatrician says when a child does something wrong you correct them and you direct them. Of course you have to control your response when the child is not your own, but you still correct and direct "Honey, you can't do/say (what they just did/said). That's not a good way to play/speak. No one wants to be treated like that. Go see your Parent/Nanny."
If they did something very dangerous or bad then you make it "Where is you Parent/Nanny, let's go talk to them." You're the adult, you're talking to a child. You have a responsibility to stand up to.

I am a mother of a 15 years old. I breastfed him when he was a baby. Back then, we were in China and lived in an apartment building. Almost all young moms hinted me that to put my baby on diet. He was Huge compared to babies of his age. His pediatrician also told me that I had to take actions to keep his " weight " in control. But my mother just loved her chubby grandson and laughed at the " nonsense. " He would thin out when he started to crawl and walk, she told me.
It was true. When my son was a toddler, he started to be more active and getting stronger and thinner. And now, he is a very handsome young man!!!

I had a friend in graduate school who was suicidal and she came to see me before driving to the mountains by herself. I asked her if she was safe to be alone or needed me to go with her and she said she wanted to go alone and would be fine. Two hours later she called after overdosing and begged me to come get her.

I found her barely conscious in her car and sped down the mountain to a hospital (had no idea how long an ambulance would take to reach us). She cried and begged me not to take her to a hospital. I told her the moment she called me she gave up all control over decision making and what she needed. I would not keep a secret that might result in her death. I took her to the hospital where her stomach was pumped and she was admitted.

She was angry with me after 3 years of our very close friendship and has not spoken with me since. Our friendship ended but today she is married with twins and she is ALIVE!

It is very difficult to tell the truth sometimes...especially when you fear the loss of relationship with the ill person. But what is the alternative?

It is not someone else's job to decide if a parent should know. Parents need to be allowed to be parents...period. If they don't know about their child's illness, for whatever reason... someone should tell them. Put yourself in a parent's shoes and the decision is obvious.

When my kid was younger, I definitely would have preferred that a parent talk to me directly - but then it is my responsibility to be present, I can't expect them to search for me before stepping in on behalf of their kid. Second thing I would have wondered is "how they said it" - I am putting it in quotes, because now that my kid is older I can see my earlier self as maybe being too sensitive on this point - but again, it is my responsibility to be there or to prepare my child for the diversity in ways that adults talk to children.

Third and perhaps key point, it is okay for a child to be upset and express the same through crying. It doesn't matter who was "wrong," you can offer a shoulder to cry on and talk about the situation if needed, and when both of you are ready to do so. Psychological impact will depend on how you and the child respond, more than what the other parent said. Even if the other parent was rude / non-gentle, you can provide a safe space for the child to share that and talk about the different angles of the situation.

I'm surprised that your schools in Chicago don't offer those managerial/entrepreneurial skills. Around here, at least, those types of programs are available. For example, Durham Technical Community College has both a program of study in Business Administration (includes management) and a certificate in entrepreneurship, as does Wake Tech. I completely agree that more people should take these courses; I'm not sure that the problem is their not being offered.

I'm stunned: you think it a good thing if poor and middle class people are pushed out of the city? And, this is because the city deserves a ...more upper class profile?

For shame.

It's capitalism. If you can afford the home for sale and there is incentive due to as what the couple describes, more room, for cheaper. They should buy it, As other homes go on sale over time, others follow. The poor and lower middle class will go where it's cheaper, as housing becomes more scarce even for upper class in the city there becomes more incentive to go out of the area as well. To Trenton, to New Haven, to Philadelphia etc.

This isn't insider trading or credit default swaps. It's not unfair, its how the housing market is. If you can't afford to live in an area, you don't live there. If you can afford to live there...you live there. If you are living there and have had the home for some time and its affordable to you as the neighborhood remakes itself, great, more incentive for you to sell, or take advantage of a now-nice area for the lower cost of what you already have.

Its the evolution of the city with a good economy. It's great to see this and I hope as this pushes out the lower classes it begins to push out people who are middle/upper class outside in regional areas. Trenton has a direct line from the Acela to NYC, not to mention NJ Transit rail to NYC from Trenton. Ideally once Harlem and other areas of NYC are done evolving into better areas, people will find its best to commute out to places like Trenton, Newark, etc. Ideally train service is upgraded to maglev high speeds that would cut the time from Philadelphia to NYC to about 30 minutes direct. As NYC enjoys a global city status, it ideally uplifts its neighboring regional cities. Of course this all takes time, for now, I'm happy to see Harlem going with the rest of NYC.

I don't disagree that Wednesday was an extremely busy news day in the NFL, but it's ridiculous to say that the Tebow trade was a bigger story than the suspensions imposed on the Saints. Perhaps there was more interest in the trade in certain markets (New York and Denver), but there's no question which was the bigger -- i.e., more significant -- story.

(a) It's actually *not* obvious that college is "money down the drain" for those who run up significant expenses yet fail to graduate. For example, I know several folks who came to college, spent a good bit of money, and dropped out - to pursue businesses. Much like Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerburg (among others), being at the university *sparked* the businesses, even if they didn't finish. So no - it's not "obvious."

(b) Your 7% to 15% return is about right - though, for most students, the return is above 7%, and the dataset used included all university graduates who had terminal bachelors (including those who took more than four years), and significantly did *not* include those who went on to gain graduate degrees (who would boost the earnings considerably). The results come from AEI, not from the "college professors" you disparage: http://www.aei.org/article/education/higher-education/is-college-worth-t...

And, as NA Expat mentions, a greater-than-7% yearly return on *any* investment is pretty darn good. Name another one that has such strong evidence of value - housing? Good luck with that. Stocks? Neither the S&P 500 or the DJIA are back at their 5-year highs - and they hit those highs, well, about 5 years ago. ROI for them: about 0%.

The important point is, as the author says, that we have to prepare students for it, and the students then have to work for it. Without those attributes, *nothing* they do with their time will be a good investment - *nothing.*

This is NOT solely a Japanese affliction. And, it's not new.

The Collyer brothers in Manhattan in 1947 were perhaps the most famous recluses who died alone. You can look it up.

Last year my neighbor was found dead in his house after several weeks worth of papers had piled up on his front steps. His children lived 3000 miles away. He probably died of grief over the loss of his most important friend ... his wife.

Sad story. Sadder still we think it can't happen in the U.S. Our seniors used to live with families to their final days. Now we ship our elders to nursing homes if we have the money. Or they die at home, poor and alone.

The Japanese can change this. The ridiculous work ethic, the subservient role of women, the irelevant Emperer, tthe Japanese stiff upper lip syndrome.
The young Japanese are leaving and going to countries with more freedom especially the women. The men are 35 year old virgins and have no interest in women and can't afford to have a family anyway.
